THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Charles
      Christopher Williams, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Greenville County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26770
Heard September 17, 2008 - Filed February
  8, 2010
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for
  Appellant
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, all of Columbia, and
  Solicitor Robert Mills Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  In this capital murder case, Charles Christopher
  Williams (Appellant) appeals his sentence of death.Â  Appellant argues (1) that
  once the jury disclosed its numerical division it was incumbent upon the trial
  judge to declare a mistrial; (2) that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 required the
  trial court to sentence Appellant to a life sentence because the jury could not
  agree on a sentence after â€œreasonable deliberation;â€ (3) the trial judge committed
  error by issuing a coercive Allen charge; and (4) the trial judge erred
  in refusing to declare a mistrial when a forensic psychiatristâ€™s testimony
  impermissibly bolstered and vouched for the solicitorâ€™s decision to seek the
  death penalty.Â  We disagree.[1]
Facts/Procedural History
Around
  10:00 a.m. on September 3, 2003, Appellant entered a Bi-Lo grocery store in
  Greenville where his former girlfriend, Maranda Williams (Victim), worked.Â 
  Appellant accosted Victim and forced her into an office in the bakery/deli.Â  Victim
  called 911 from her cell phone.Â  During the ninety-minute phone call, hostage
  negotiators tried to convince Appellant to release Victim.Â  When Victim
  attempted to escape Appellant chased, shot, and killed her.Â  Hearing the shots,
  law enforcement entered the store and apprehended Appellant.Â  Shortly after his
  arrest, Appellant gave a statement in which he confessed to the crimes for
  which he was later charged.Â  
Appellant
  was tried and found guilty of murder, kidnapping, and possession of a firearm
  during the commission of a violent crime.Â  During the sentencing phase of the
  trial, the State sought to establish two statutory aggravating circumstances:
  (1) the murder was committed while in the commission of kidnapping; and (2) the
  offender by his act of murder knowingly created a great risk of death to more
  than one person in a public place by means of a weapon. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-3-20(C)(a)(1)(b), (C)(a)(3) (2003 & Supp. 2007).Â  As its primary
  witness, the State called Dr. Pamela Crawford.Â  Dr. Crawford testified that she
  was associated with SLED and called by the Greenville County Solicitorâ€™s Office
  within an hour and fifteen minutes of the crime to â€œprovide assistance.â€[2] 
Defense
  counsel objected to Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony and argued that it amounted to
  expert testimony.Â  The trial judge sustained the objection and gave a curative
  instruction telling the jury to disregard anything Dr. Crawford said about the
  death penalty.Â  
The
  solicitor resumed his questioning of Dr. Crawford and asked, â€œ[w]as the purpose
  of you interviewing the defendant to provide information to me in consideration
  of whether or not - - -.â€Â  Before the solicitor could finish the question,
  defense counsel again objected and the jury was sent out of the courtroom.Â 
  Defense counsel renewed his objection and emphasized that Dr. Crawford had not
  been qualified as an expert but was giving testimony that she assisted the
  solicitor in whether to seek the death penalty.Â  Defense counsel then moved to
  have Dr. Crawford excused as a witness.Â  The solicitor stated he would withdraw
  the question.Â  Defense counsel explained he believed the jury would think that
  the defense was hiding relevant evidence by objecting to Dr. Crawfordâ€™s
  testimony.Â  Defense counsel then moved for a mistrial.Â  The trial judge
  reminded defense counsel that the question was withdrawn, but defense counsel
  responded with a demand for a mistrial.
The
  Court denied the motion for a mistrial.Â  After a lunch break, Dr. Crawford was
  called back to the stand and defense counsel renewed the motion for a
  mistrial.Â  The judge gave a curative instruction in which he told the jury that
  Dr. Crawford had not been qualified as an expert.Â  Dr. Crawford then resumed
  her testimony.Â Â  
Dr.
  Crawford testified that she interviewed Appellant for several hours at the
  Greenville County Law Enforcement Center.[3]Â  According to Dr. Crawford, the primary purpose of
  this interview was to understand Appellantâ€™s state of mind at the time of the
  crime.Â  At the outset of the interview, Dr. Crawford informed Appellant she was
  a forensic psychiatrist who worked for SLED and the solicitorâ€™s office, and any
  information she obtained could be used in court.Â  Dr. Crawford also emphasized
  to Appellant that she was not his treating psychiatrist but would refer him to
  someone if she felt he needed treatment.Â  Although Appellant was not very
  expressive during the interview, Dr. Crawford testified that Appellant was
  coherent and characterized his demeanor as calm, pleasant, and cooperative.Â 
  During the interview, Appellant again confessed to murdering Victim and
  explained his feelings and the events leading up to the crime.Â  
After
  motions, closing arguments, and charges, the jury deliberated from 3:50 p.m. to
  7:00 p.m. on Friday, February 18, 2005.Â  The jury resumed deliberations the
  next morning at 9:30.Â  Shortly before 11:55 a.m., the foreman sent the trial judge
  a note which stated: â€œ[the] jury is at 9 for death imposition, 3 for life
  imprisonment.Â  Please refer to instruction about what procedure to follow to
  resolve.â€Â  
The
  judge, out of the presence of the jury, indicated that he intended to give an Allen charge.[4]Â  Defense counsel moved for a mistrial arguing that
  because the jury indicated its division as to a life versus death sentence the
  judge was required to end the juryâ€™s deliberations and impose a sentence of
  life without parole.Â  The solicitor disagreed, noting the jury had voluntarily
  revealed its voting division, thus the judge was not required to impose a
  sentence of life imprisonment.Â  
Defense
  counsel made a motion for a mistrial, motion to sentence Appellant to life
  imprisonment, and a motion to charge the defenseâ€™s proposed Allen instruction.Â  The trial judge denied all of defense counselâ€™s motions.Â  The trial
  judge then informed counsel that he intended to give the jury an Allen charge and would instruct them to continue their deliberations.
After
  the judge issued an Allen charge, the jury resumed deliberations at
  12:02 p.m.Â  At 3:45 p.m., the jury returned to the courtroom after indicating
  they had reached a verdict.Â  The jury found beyond a reasonable doubt that the
  murder was committed while in the commission of a kidnapping, and the jury
  recommended Appellant be sentenced to death.Â  The trial judge then sentenced Appellant
  to death.[5]
Standard of Review
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. We are
  bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.â€ Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C.
  1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (citations omitted).Â  â€œThis Court does not
  re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by
  any evidence.â€Â  Id. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.Â  â€œThe admission or
  exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge, whose
  decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  State
    v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2001).Â  
Law/Analysis
I.  Juryâ€™s Disclosure of Vote
  Division
Appellant argues the trial judge erred in declining to
  sentence him to life imprisonment when the jury, by its written note, revealed
  it was divided nine to three in favor of death.Â  Appellant contends that under
  these â€œunusual circumstancesâ€ giving the jury an Allen charge was
  impractical and coercive against the minority faction of the jury that opposed
  the death penalty.Â  Ultimately, Appellant argues that once the jury disclosed
  its numerical division it was incumbent upon the trial judge to declare a
  mistrial.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â  
As
  a threshold matter, â€œ[n]either the Due Process clause nor the Eighth Amendment
  forbid the giving of an Allen charge in the sentencing phase of a
  capital proceeding.â€Â  Tucker v. Catoe, 346 S.C. 483, 490, 552 S.E.2d
  712, 716 (2001) (citing Lowenfield v. Phelps, 484 U.S. 231 (1988); Jones
    v. United States, 527 U.S. 373 (1999)).Â  â€œThe typical judicial mechanism
  for encouraging an indecisive jury is the Allen charge, in which jurors
  are instructed on, among other things, their duties to approach the evidence
  with an open mind and consider the opinions of their fellow jurors.â€Â  State
    v. Robinson, 360 S.C. 187, 193, 600 S.E.2d 100, 103 (Ct. App. 2004). 
We
  find the trial judgeâ€™s issuance of an Allen charge was not improper.Â 
  Initially, we agree with Appellant that it is improper for a trial judge to
  inquire into the numerical division of a jury.Â  See State v.
    Middleton, 218 S.C. 452, 457, 63 S.E.2d 163, 165 (1951); Lowenfield,
  484 U.S. at 239-40 Brasfield v. United States, 272 U.S. 448, 450
  (1926).Â Â Â Â  However, these decisions are inapplicable in the instant case
  because the jury here voluntarily disclosed its numerical division and
  requested further instructions on how to proceed.Â  The judge then promptly
  informed the attorneys of the jurorsâ€™ numerical division and indicated that he
  could give an Allen charge.Â  Unlike other cases, the trial judge did not
  inquire about the specifics of the juryâ€™s impasse.Â  See United States
    v. Brokemond, 959 F.2d 206, 209 (11th Cir. 1992) (â€œUnsolicited disclosure
  of the juryâ€™s division by a juror is not by itself grounds for a mistrial.â€).Â 
  Therefore, we hold the trial judge committed no error in not declaring a
  mistrial and giving an Allen charge after the jury revealed it was
  divided nine to three in favor of death.
II.  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20
Appellant argues that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20
  required the trial court to sentence Appellant to a life sentence because the
  jury could not agree on a sentence after â€œreasonable deliberation.â€Â  We
  disagree.Â Â Â  

	Section 16-3-20
  provides in pertinent part:
	If members of
  the jury after a reasonable deliberation cannot agree on a recommendation as to
  whether or not the death sentence should be imposed on a defendant found guilty
  of murder, the trial judge shall dismiss such jury and shall sentence the
  defendant to life imprisonment as provided in subsection (A).

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C) (2003).Â  A review of the pertinent statutory language in
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C) reveals the analysis of this issue is dependent
  upon an interpretation of â€œreasonable deliberation.â€ Â Given the subjective
  nature of this term, this Court has been reluctant to define as a matter of law
  what constitutes â€œreasonable deliberationâ€ sufficient to end the juryâ€™s
  deliberations and impose a life sentence. Â We note that â€œâ€˜reasonable
  deliberationâ€™ is not simply an elapsed-time dependent determination,â€ but
  rather is an issue â€œcommitted to the trial judgeâ€™s discretion.â€Â  Tucker,
  346 S.C. at 489-90, 552 S.E.2d at 715.
Although we have not precisely defined â€œreasonable
  deliberation,â€ our previous decisions make clear that here the trial judge did
  not abuse his discretion in permitting the jury to resume deliberations.Â  In Tucker,
  this Court refused to determine as a matter of law that the jury had engaged in
  â€œreasonable deliberationâ€ sufficient to require the trial judge to impose a
  life sentence.Â  Id. at 490, 552 S.E.2d at 716.Â  We found that the jury
  deliberated for a substantial period of time before informing the judge it was
  â€œhopelessly deadlocked,â€ and that the jury took its responsibility seriously,
  diligently working to reach a verdict.Â  Id. at 490, 552 S.E.2d at 715.Â 
  Under those circumstances, had the â€œreasonable deliberationâ€ issue been raised
  to him, the trial judge in his discretion â€œmay or may not have found the jury
  had engaged in â€˜reasonable deliberation.â€™â€Â  Id. at 490, 552 S.E.2d at
  716.Â  
Here, the jury only deliberated about a lengthy
  capital murder trial for approximately five hours and thirty-five minutes
  before sending the note to the judge.Â  However, unlike the jury in Tucker,
  this jury did not indicate it was deadlocked, but rather requested additional
  instructions to resolve their impasse.Â  Cf. State v. Robinson, 360 S.C.
  187, 193-94, 600 S.E.2d 100, 103 (Ct. App. 2004) (concluding mistrial should
  have been granted after jury indicated it was again deadlocked after receiving Allen charge and that additional deliberation would not break deadlock).Â  Thus, the
  juryâ€™s request was an indication that the jurors had not given up on reaching a
  verdict and that they anticipated further deliberations.Â  Accordingly, we hold
  the trial judge properly permitted the jury to resume its deliberations and
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 did not mandate a sentence of life imprisonment.
III.  Allen Charge Not Coercive
Alternatively,
  Appellant argues that the trial judgeâ€™s Allen charge was unconstitutionally
  coercive.Â  We disagree.Â  
Because we find the trial judge properly charged
  Appellantâ€™s jury with an Allen charge, the question before us is whether
  the charge was coercive.Â  â€œWhether an Allen charge is unconstitutionally
  coercive must be judged â€˜in its context and under all the circumstances.â€™â€Â  Tucker,
  346 S.C. at 490, 552 S.E.2d at 716 (quoting Lowenfield, 484 U.S. at
  237).Â  This Court has explained:Â Â  

	In South Carolina state courts, an Allen charge
  cannot be directed to the minority voters on the jury panel.Â  Instead, an Allen charge should be even-handed, directing both the majority and the minority to
  consider the otherâ€™s views.Â  A trial judge has a duty to urge, but not coerce,
  a jury to reach a verdict.Â  It is not coercion to charge every juror has a
  right to his own opinion and need not give up the opinion merely to reach a
  verdict.Â  

Green
  v. State, 351 S.C. 184, 194, 569
  S.E.2d 318, 323 (2002) (citations omitted).Â  
In Tucker, we adopted the standard set by the United States Supreme Court
  in Lowenfield to determine whether an Allen charge is
  unconstitutionally coercive.Â  In Lowenfield, the Supreme Court set forth
  the following factors to be considered:

	(1) the charge did not speak specifically to the
  minority juror(s);Â Â  
	(2) the judge did not include in his charge any
  language such as â€œYou have got to reach a decision in this case;â€
	(3) there was no inquiry into the juryâ€™s numerical
  division, which is generally coercive; and
	(4) while the jury returned a verdict shortly after
  the supplemental charge, which suggests a possibility of coercion, weighing
  against this is the fact that trial counsel did not object either to the
  inquiry into whether the jurors believed further deliberation would result in a
  verdict, nor to the supplemental charge.

Tucker, 346 S.C. at 492, 552 S.E.2d at 716 (citing Lowenfield,
  484 U.S. at 237).Â Â  
Applying
  these factors, we found the Allen charge in Tucker was
  unconstitutionally coercive.Â  Id. at 494, 552 S.E.2d at 718.Â 
  Specifically, this Court concluded: (1) viewed as a whole, the jury charge was
  directed to the minority juror; (2) Tuckerâ€™s jury was told of the importance of
  a unanimous verdict; (3) even though the jury informed the trial judge of their
  numerical split, the judge failed to instruct the jurors not to disclose their
  division in the future; and (4) Tuckerâ€™s jury returned a verdict approximately
  an hour and a half after receiving the Allen charge.Â  Id. at
  492-94, 552 S.E.2d at 717-18.Â  
In
  this case, defense counsel took exception to the judgeâ€™s Allen charge on
  the ground that it deviated from counselâ€™s proposed instruction. Â Defense
  counselâ€™s proposed Allen charge stated:Â  

	By law I cannot tell you where to go from here, but I
  suggest that you continue deliberations in an attempt to reach a verdict.Â  I
  can tell you that each of you have a duty to consult with one another and to
  deliberate with a view to reaching an agreement that does not do violence to
  any one of your individual judgments.Â  Each of you as jurors must decide the
  case for yourself after impartial consideration of the evidence with your
  fellow jurors.Â  During the course of your continued deliberations each of you
  should not hesitate to re-examine your own views and change your opinion if
  convinced that your opinion is erroneous.Â  Each juror who finds himself or
  herself to be in the minority should consider their views in light of the
  opinions of the jurors of the majority.Â  Those in the majority must consider
  their views in light of the minority.Â  No juror should surrender their honest
  conviction for the mere purpose of returning a unanimous verdict.Â Â  

In response to defense counselâ€™s exceptions, the trial
  court noted that the charge issued covered â€œbasically the same thingâ€ as the
  submitted Allen charge.Â  The trial judge also referenced counselâ€™s
  concern that the jury be instructed that they should not surrender their
  convictions just to get a unanimous vote. Â The trial judge read the following
  portion of his original charge: â€œLadies and gentlemen, you have stated you are
  unable to agree on a verdict in this case.Â  As I instructed you earlier, the
  verdict of a jury must be unanimous.â€Â  The judge then stated, â€œI am not going
  to charge that.Â  Iâ€™m taking that sentence out.â€Â  The trial judge then
  instructed the jury:

	Mr. Foreman, Ladies and Gentlemen of the jury, youâ€™ve
  stated youâ€™ve been unable to reach a verdict in this case.Â  When a matter is in
  dispute, it isnâ€™t always easy for even two people to agree.Â  So, when 12 people
  must agree, it becomes even more difficult.Â  In most cases absolute certainty
  cannot be reached or expected.Â  You should consult with one another, express
  your own views, and listen to the opinions of your fellow jurors.Â  Tell each
  other how you feel and why you feel that way.Â  Discuss your differences with
  open minds.Â  Therefore, to some degree it can be said jury service is a matter
  of give and take.
	Every one of you has the right to your own opinion,
  the verdict you agree to must be your own verdict, a result of your own
  convictions.Â  You should not give up your firmly held beliefs merely to be in
  agreement with your fellow jurors.Â  The minority should consider the majorityâ€™s
  opinion and the majority should consider the minorityâ€™s opinion.Â  You should
  carefully consider and respect the opinions of each other and evaluate your
  position for reasonableness, correctness, and partiality.Â  You must lay aside
  all outside matters and reexamine the question before you base[d] [on] the law
  and the evidence in this case.Â  
	I, therefore, ask you to return to your deliberations
  with the hope that you can arrive at a verdict.Â Â Â  

Defense
  counsel again objected to the trial judgeâ€™s charge.Â  Relying on this Courtâ€™s
  opinion in State v. Hughes, 336 S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500 (1999),[6] counsel claimed that his proposed charge
  â€œspecifically identifies to the jurors that they have the right and
  specifically essentially an obligation to deal with their own views in this
  case and not to agree simply to agree.â€Â  The trial judge denied counselâ€™s
  motion and explained that his charge covered defense counselâ€™s concern by
  charging the jury to maintain their own convictions.Â  Â Â Â 
We
  find the Allen charge in the instant case was not coercive.Â  First,
  unlike Tucker, the charge was not directed at the minority jurors.Â 
  Instead, it evenly addressed both the majority and minority jurors and urged
  them to consider each otherâ€™s views.Â  See Green, 351 S.C. at 195, 569
  S.E.2d at 323-24 (finding Allen charge was not coercive and did not
  focus on the position of the minority juror).Â  Second, the trial judgeâ€™s charge
  did not include language such as â€œYou have got to reach a decision in this
  case.â€Â  Rather, the charge instructed the jurors to resume their deliberations
  â€œwith the hope you can arrive at a verdict.â€Â  Third, there was no inquiry into
  the juryâ€™s numerical division.Â  Here, without solicitation the jury disclosed
  its numerical division to the trial judge who then informed the trial
  attorneys.Â  In contrast to Tucker where there was one holdout juror, the
  judge here did not direct his Allen charge to the three minority jurors
  despite his knowledge of the juryâ€™s numerical split.Â  Finally, the jury
  deliberated for approximately three hours and forty-five minutes after being
  given the Allen charge, which was significantly longer than the Tucker jury.Â  We believe the extended deliberations would appear to weigh against any
  allegation that the charge was coercive.
Viewing
  the Allen charge in the context of the specific circumstances of the
  case, we find it was not coercive.[7]Â  Furthermore, a careful review of the trial judgeâ€™s
  charge compared with defense counselâ€™s proposed charge reveals the charge was a
  correct statement of the law and covered the substance of defense counselâ€™s
  proposed charge.Â  See State v. Austin, 299 S.C. 456, 458, 385
  S.E.2d 830, 831 (1989) (stating, â€œ[I]f the trial judge refuses to give a
  specific charge, there is no error if the charge actually given sufficiently
  covers the substance of the request.â€).
IV.  Dr. Crawfordâ€™s Testimony
Appellant
  argues the trial judge erred in refusing to declare a mistrial because Dr.
  Crawfordâ€™s testimony impermissibly bolstered and vouched for the solicitorâ€™s decision
  to seek the death penalty.[8]Â 
  We disagree.Â Â  
We find that there was nothing improper about the
  solicitorâ€™s examination of Dr. Crawford as a lay witness.Â  Furthermore, to the
  extent there was any confusion among the jurors regarding Dr. Crawfordâ€™s role
  as a lay witness, such confusion was effectively cured by the trial courtâ€™s
  instruction to the jury.Â  
Dr. Crawford was introduced to give fact testimony
  regarding her observation of Appellantâ€™s mental state within hours of Victimâ€™s
  murder.Â  We have long held that a lay witness may testify as to a defendantâ€™s
  mental state.Â  See State
    v. Rimert, 315 S.C. 527, 446 S.E.2d 400 (1994), cert.
      denied, 513 U.S. 1080 (1995) (where the State relied on lay testimony to
  establish defendantâ€™s sanity); State v. Smith, 298 S.C. 205, 379 S.E.2d
  287 (1989) (holding that where defendant presents expert testimony regarding
  his insanity, the State may introduce lay testimony in rebuttal).Â  Â Â 
We recognize that while a witness of Dr. Crawfordâ€™s
  professional expertise may in many cases be called upon to deliver expert
  testimony, the solicitor was not bound to call her in that capacity so long as
  her testimony was limited to lay matters.Â  The solicitor was justified in
  asking Dr. Crawford to observe Appellantâ€™s mental state subsequent to his
  arrest and in calling upon her to testify regarding her observations.Â 
  Appellant had been duly informed of his rights under Miranda, and spoke
  with Dr. Crawford voluntarily.Â  Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony was reasonably limited
  to her factual observations over the course of the interview.Â  In our view, Dr.
  Crawford was called as a lay witness to give lay testimony.Â  There is no
  indication in the record that the juryâ€™s responsibility for determining Appellantâ€™s
  fate was diminished in any way by the solicitorâ€™s questioning of Dr. Crawford.Â  
Even if Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony was improper, any
  prejudice was cured by the jury instruction.Â  Therefore, we find no error in the
  trial judgeâ€™s denial of Appellantâ€™s motion for mistrial.
Proportionality Review
Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C) (2003), we
  have conducted a proportionality review and find the death
  sentence was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary
  factor.Â  Furthermore, a review of other decisions demonstrates that Appellantâ€™s
  sentence is neither excessive nor disproportionate. Â See, e.g., State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996).Â  
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we hold (1) the trial judge
  committed no error in not declaring a mistrial and giving an Allen charge after the jury revealed it was divided nine to three in favor of death; (2)
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 did not mandate a sentence of life imprisonment; (3) the
  trial judgeâ€™s Allen charge was not coercive; and (4) the trial judge committed
  no error in refusing to declare a mistrial based on Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony.Â 
  The conviction and sentence below are therefore affirmed.Â  
WALLER, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  KITTREDGE, J.,
  concurring except for Part IV in which he concurs in result only.Â  PLEICONES,
  J., concurring in a separate opinion.Â  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in the majorityâ€™s decision to affirm here,
  but write separately to express my disagreement with Part IV of the majorityâ€™s
  opinion.Â  In my opinion, whether the trial judge committed an abuse of
  discretion in denying appellantâ€™s mistrial motion following improper questioning
  by the solicitor is not preserved for our review.
The sole issue
  regarding Dr. Crawford before the Court at this juncture is whether the trial
  judge should have granted a mistrial because of Dr. Crawfordâ€™s penalty phase
  testimony.Â  To explain why I do not believe this issue is preserved, I will
  quote liberally from the penalty phase transcript of the solicitorâ€™s
  questioning of Dr. Crawford:

	Solicitor:Â  And your employment with the Department of
  Mental Health is as what?
	Answer:Â Â Â  A forensic psychiatrist.
	
		
			Solicitor: 
			And, now, back on September the 3rd, did 
			you have occasion at my request to come to Greenville, South 
			Carolina?
		
	
	Answer:Â Â Â  Yes, I did.
	Solicitor:Â  As an employee of the Department of Mental
  Health?
	Answer:Â  Thatâ€™s correct.
	Solicitor:Â  And were you also in any way connected
  with any other state agency at that time?
	
		
			Answer: 
			Yes.  The Department of Mental Health had what 
			we call a memorandum of agreement with SLED, South Carolina Law 
			Enforcement Division, where I was the consultant forensic 
			psychiatrist for SLED.
		
	
	
		
			Solicitor:
			Explain to the jury prior to September the 3rd 
			of 2003, what the working relationship you had either with my office 
			or other solicitors.
		
	
	
		
			Answer: 
			This was all through my work with Department of 
			Mental Health, through the memorandum of agreement with SLED.  
			I would do a variety of things.  Some of the things I would do, 
			for example, go on SWAT calls and assist with negotiations.  
			But as far as your office and the solicitorâ€™s office is concerned, I 
			would be called by a solicitor if, for example, there was some kind 
			of alleged crime of significant magnitude.  And they would call 
			me and ask me to come and provide assistance.
		
	
	Solicitor:Â  All right.Â  What type of assistance in
  particular did I request from you in this particular case on September the 3rd?
	
		
			Answer: 
			In this particular case, and again Iâ€™m called by 
			various solicitors throughout the state, and Iâ€™m only called when 
			itâ€™s a case of a very severe nature.  And typically itâ€™s when 
			the death penalty may be considered.  And Iâ€™m asked to assess -
		
	
	Mr. Nettles:Â  Objection.Â  And Iâ€™m going to ask the
  jury be sent out.
	The Court:Â  Mr. foreman, members of the jury donâ€™t
  discuss the case.Â  Iâ€™ll get you back very shortly.

After
  an in camera discussion, the judge gave the following curative
  instruction, without objection from appellant, and the questioning continued:

	
		
			The Court:
			Mr. foreman, ladies and gentlemen of the jury 
			please disregard anything that she said that she may be asked to 
			assess concerning the death penalty.  Disregard that.  
			Thatâ€™s not appropriate.  Weâ€™re not going there. 
		
	
	
		Solicitor.
	
	
		
			Solicitor: 
			Let me clarify and go back.Â  We were
  talking about what you had come to Greenville for.Â  And as a result of coming
  to Greenville, did you in fact interview the defendant?
		
	
	Answer:Â Â Â   Yes, I did.
	Solicitor:Â    What was the purpose of you interviewing -
	Mr. Nettles:Â Objection.
	
		
			The Court:
			Hold on a second.  Solicitor, you may lead her 
			through these questions, please, sir, laying your foundation.  
			You may lead her.
		
	
	
	
		
			Mr. Ariail: 
			Was the purpose of you interviewing the
  defendant to provide that information to me in consideration of whether or not
  -
		
	
	Mr. Nettles:Â Objection.Â  And Iâ€™m going to -
	The Court:Â   Hold on.Â  Donâ€™t get into the facts.Â  Come
  on up here for a second, both of you.
	Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â     (bench conference held within the
  presence but outside the hearing of the jury.)
	The Court:Â  Mr. foreman, ladies and gentlemen, go to
  the jury room.Â  Donâ€™t discuss the case please.

During
  the ensuing in camera discussion, the solicitor agreed to withdraw the
  question.Â  One of appellantâ€™s attorneys requested a curative instruction, and
  was given an opportunity to write one for the trial judgeâ€™s use.Â  While that
  charge was being written, appellantâ€™s other attorney argued for a mistrial.[9]Â  The judge denied the mistrial request, but gave the
  solicitor and Dr. Crawford strict instructions on the limits of permissible
  questions and answers.Â  Following that, appellant renewed his mistrial motion.Â 
  When the jury returned, they were given this curative instruction:

	The Court:Â  Mr. foreman, members of the jury, I told
  you this in the first phase of the trial.Â  Iâ€™m going to tell you again.Â 
  Whenever one of the attorneys makes an objection, theyâ€™re merely telling the
  court that they do not think thatâ€™s admissible under the rules of evidence or
  the rules of court.Â  And itâ€™s my job to decide whether itâ€™s admissible or not
  admissible.Â  I ask you to leave the courtroom so I can comment on the facts,
  because Iâ€™m not at liberty to comment on the facts when the jury is present.
	Iâ€™m the one that asked
  you to leave the courtroom so I can be free with what I say to the attorneys
  and the questions I ask the attorneys.Â  The attorneys are not trying to hide
  anything, they just have an opinion itâ€™s not admissible, and thatâ€™s their job.Â 
  You are not to consider anything for or against either one of the attorneys
  when they make objections as to the rules of evidence.Â  Thatâ€™s the procedure we
  are going through, and thatâ€™s the reason Iâ€™ve been running you in and out of
  the courtroom, so I would be free, not that the attorneys are hiding anything.Â 
  You understand?
	All right.Â  Now, normally
  opinions are not given in a courtroom.Â  However, opinions may be given in a
  courtroom by laypersons when theyâ€™re based on the perceptions of a witness,
  such as, if someone is staggering and you smell alcohol on their breath, you
  have an opinion theyâ€™re intoxicated, thatâ€™s a lay opinion that may be
  admissible in a courtroom; or if itâ€™s going to be helpful for the jury to
  understand and does not require special skill, experience, or training.
	An expert may give his
  opinion if they qualify when thereâ€™s a scientifically, technical, or other
  specialized knowledge required for the jury to understand the question.
	Now, in this particular
  case this witness has not been qualified as an expert.Â  In order for an expert
  to give an opinion, they have to be qualified.Â  And the court has to find that
  theyâ€™re qualified.Â  This witness has not been qualified as an expert and Iâ€™m
  going to tell you, you must disregard any suggestion either in the solicitorâ€™s
  questions or any answer that this witness has given an opinion of any kind in
  this case.Â  Sheâ€™s going to be treated as a lay witness, not an expert.
	
		Solicitor.
	

Appellant
  made no objection to the sufficiency of this instruction, but argues on appeal
  that the trial judge erred in failing to grant a mistrial.Â  In my opinion, this
  issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  As the factual recital above
  demonstrates, appellant did not seek a mistrial when the solicitor first
  questioned Dr. Crawford about her consulting role, and her assessments in
  serious death-penalty type cases.Â  Instead, appellant merely objected.Â  The
  trial judge sustained the objection and gave a curative instruction, to which
  appellant did not object.Â  Since appellant accepted this ruling and neither
  objected to the chargeâ€™s sufficiency nor moved for a mistrial following it, no
  issue regarding these questions and answers are preserved for our review.Â  See,
    e.g., State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 476 S.E.2d 903 (1996).
When
  the solicitor resumed his improper questioning, the trial judge sustained the
  objection.Â  One of appellantâ€™s attorneys sought a curative instruction; the
  other, a mistrial.Â  Following the in camera arguments, the judge denied
  the second attorneyâ€™s mistrial motion but then gave, again without objection,
  the curative instruction apparently drafted by the otherÂ  lawyer.Â  Under these
  circumstances, the mistrial issue is not before us.Â  State v. George, supra; cf. State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 1999) (mistrial motion arguably preserved where trial attorney specified he did
  not â€œwaiveâ€ mistrial motion after hearing curative instruction).Â  Here,
  appellant did not renew or reserve his mistrial motion after hearing the
  curative instruction drafted by his own attorney, apparently finding it
  sufficiently cured any prejudice from the solicitorâ€™s improper questioning.Â 
  Accordingly, there is no mistrial issue before the Court.
Although
  I do not believe the mistrial issue is preserved, because it is addressed, and
  because I differ in my assessment, I comment briefly.Â  The Stateâ€™s position is
  that Dr. Crawford was being offered merely as a â€œfactâ€ witness.Â  If this is so,
  then her education, her training, her profession, and her special relationship
  with the solicitorâ€™s office are irrelevant.Â  The only reason to allow this
  background evidence is to enhance Dr. Crawfordâ€™s credentials, that is, to
  permit the jury to view her testimony in light of her expertise.Â  Compare State v. Douglas, 380 S.C. 499, 671 S.E.2d 606 (2009) (testimony from
  expert clothed â€œwith an air of authority that does not attach to â€œordinary
  witnessesâ€â€) (Pleicones, J., dissenting).
Moreover,
  I do not understand why Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony, offered allegedly to show
  appellantâ€™s mental state, was relevant in this penalty phase.Â  The State sought
  to prove two aggravating circumstances, neither of which involved appellantâ€™s
  state of mind.Â  Had appellant put his mental state at the time of the offense
  in issue, then Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony as to her â€œlayâ€ observations in the
  hours surrounding the offense would be relevant.Â  Here, however, Dr. Crawfordâ€™s
  testimony was offered only to bolster the solicitorâ€™s decision that this case
  warranted a death sentence.Â  Unlike the majority, I do not see how the curative
  instruction negates the prejudice from Dr. Crawfordâ€™s irrelevant yet
  prejudicial testimony.

[1] This case consolidates Appellantâ€™s direct appeal and the mandatory review
  provisions of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25 (2003).Â  
[2] Dr. Crawfordâ€™s employment by the Department of Mental Health required her to do
  a variety of things, including going on SWAT calls and providing assistance to
  prosecutors.Â  
[3] Dr. Crawford interviewed Appellant the evening of the crime and the next morning.Â 
  Dr. Crawford and the investigating officers testified that Appellant was
  apprised of his rights prior to these interviews pursuant to Miranda v.
    Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).Â  
[4] Allen v. United States, 164 U.S. 492 (1896) (establishing the charge used
  to encourage a deadlocked jury to reach a verdict). 
[5] At a post-trial hearing, the trial judge denied all of defense counselâ€™s
  motions.
[6] In Hughes, this Court determined an Allen charge was an
  â€œeven-handed admonition to both the minority and majority jurorsâ€ where it
  stated: â€œEach juror who finds himself or herself to be in the minority should
  reconsider their views in light of the opinions of the jurors of the majority
  and, conversely each juror finding themselves in the majority should give equal
  consideration to the views of the minority.â€Â  Hughes, 336 S.C. at
  597-98, 521 S.E.2d at 507.Â  
[7] Although we find no reversible error in the Allen charge in this case,
  we take this opportunity to caution trial judges against using the following
  language: â€œwith the hope that you can arrive at a verdict.â€Â  Because jurors are
  not required to reach a verdict after expressing that they are deadlocked, we
  believe this language could potentially be construed as being coercive.Â 
  Furthermore, to alleviate problems in future cases where the jury is
  deadlocked, we would advise trial judges to instruct the jurors not to disclose
  their numerical division.Â  
[8] The question of whether the trial judge committed
  an abuse of discretion in denying Appellantâ€™s mistrial motion is preserved for
  our review.Â  Appellant objected to Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony before it was given
  and renewed this objection both during and after her testimony.Â  Appellant
  moved for mistrial on these grounds, and the trial judge denied the motion.Â 
  Appellant then sought to introduce a curative instruction, which the trial
  judge accepted.Â  Under these circumstances, the trial judgeâ€™s denial of the
  mistrial motion is properly preserved for appellate review.Â  See State v. Rogers, 361 S.C. 178, 183, 603 S.E.2d 910, 912-13 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œâ€˜There are four
  basic requirements to preserving issues at trial for appellate review. Â The
  issue must have been (1) raised to and ruled upon by the trial court, (2)
  raised by the appellant, (3) raised in a timely manner, and (4) raised to the
  trial court with sufficient specificity.â€™â€) (quoting Jean Hoefer Toal et al., Appellate
  Practice in South Carolina 57 (2d ed. 2002)). 
[9] In my view, the better practice is to permit only one of the attorneys to
  object to evidence.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        J. Lamar Kolle, Respondent,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L. Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26771
  Submitted October 21, 2009 - Filed
February 16, 2010Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Daniel E.
          Grigg, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Appellate
          Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  This Court granted the State's
  petition for a writ of certiorari to review the post-conviction relief (PCR)
  judge's order granting J. Lamar Kolle a new trial following his plea of guilty
  to trafficking in cocaine in an amount greater than 28 grams but less than 100
  grams.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On July 12, 2003, Officer Vincent Canfora received a
  phone call at approximately 11:30 p.m. concerning a complaint about loud music
  at the Myrtle Beach apartment where Kolle was staying.Â  When he arrived between
  11:45 p.m. to 12:00 a.m., Officer Canfora heard music coming from inside the
  apartment.Â  As he knocked on the door, he observed "fresh damage" to
  the door, which appeared to be forced entry marks.Â  Although the door seemed to
  be open, Officer Canfora knocked on it for approximately five to ten minutes
  while announcing he was a police officer.Â  Receiving no response, he then
  knocked on the window beside the door.Â  Because there were lights on in the
  apartment and no one answered his knocks, Officer Canfora "presumed that
  there may be something wrong inside the apartment . . . that somebody was in
  the residence, maybe injured or incapacitated."Â  
Based
  on his assessment of the situation, Officer Canfora called for a back-up
  officer to assist him with making an entry into the apartment.Â  Lance Corporal
  Steven Atwood responded to the scene within three minutes of receiving Officer
  Canfora's call.Â  The two officers then decided to enter the apartment by
  pushing on the door.Â Â  Upon entering, the officers announced themselves as
  police officers and asked if anyone inside the residence needed assistance.Â  Once
  inside, the officers conducted a protective search of the residence.Â  During
  this protective search, Officer Canfora observed a small plate with a moderate
  amount of what appeared to be cocaine, partially covered by a saltine cracker,
  drying under an elevated oscillating fan.Â  The officers also noticed a large
  steel press used for processing and manufacturing cocaine as well as other
  materials commonly used for processing or cutting cocaine.Â  Finding no one in
  the apartment, the officers seized the small amount of cocaine-like substance
  and returned to the police department.Â  After the substance field-tested
  positive for cocaine, Officer Canfora completed an application for a search
  warrant for the apartment based on the cocaine seized during the initial entry.Â 
  According to Officer Canfora, he and another narcotics officer prepared the
  warrant at approximately 12:30 a.m.
After
  obtaining the search warrant from a municipal judge, Officer Canfora returned
  to the residence at approximately 12:43 a.m. with his lieutenant and another
  narcotics officer in order to execute the warrant. Â As the officers knocked on
  the door, Sharon Hakes opened the door.Â  Once inside, the officers presented
  Hakes, Jessica Everhart, and Kolle with a copy of the search warrant.Â  During the
  subsequent search, Officer Canfora discovered a bag of flour in a kitchen
  cabinet that contained approximately sixty-three grams of cocaine.Â  
As a
  result, the officers arrested Kolle, Hakes, and Everhart.[1]Â 
  Shortly thereafter, the officers also arrested Willis Holmes, the resident
  named on the apartment lease.Â  
Subsequently, the Horry County grand jury indicted
  Kolle for trafficking in cocaine in an amount of more than 28 grams but less
  than 100 grams.Â  In response to the charge, Kolle's public defender filed a
  discovery motion with the solicitor's office.Â  Ultimately, this requested information
  was turned over by the solicitor's office to plea counsel, a private attorney
  retained by Kolle.Â  In addition to the public defender's discovery motion, plea
  counsel filed a motion in which he requested "any and all search warrants
  applied for and a copy of all dispatch logs from the North Myrtle Beach Police
  Department."
 Based on his review
  of the discovery information, plea counsel moved to suppress evidence seized
  pursuant to the search warrant.Â Â Â  After a hearing, the trial judge denied this
  motion on the ground there were exigent circumstances to justify the officers'
  entry into the apartment.Â  Additionally, the judge ruled the officers saw the
  cocaine in plain view.Â  As a result, the judge concluded the search was valid.Â  
On the day of this
  ruling, Kolle pled guilty to trafficking cocaine in an amount greater than 28
  grams but less than 100 grams. Â The plea judge sentenced Kolle to seven years
  in prison.Â  
Kolle did not
  appeal his plea or sentence.Â  Four months after the plea proceeding, Kolle
  filed a PCR application.Â  In this application, Kolle alleged he was being held
  in custody unlawfully based on the following grounds:Â  the trafficking charge
  arose out of an unlawful search and seizure; the plea judge lacked subject
  matter jurisdiction due to an invalid indictment; and he did not receive all of
  the discovery materials that he was entitled to pursuant to Brady v.
    Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).Â  
Underlying
  these allegations, Kolle primarily contended plea counsel was ineffective in
  failing to:Â  procure certain discovery materials; thoroughly advocate the
  suppression of the drug evidence; properly advise him regarding plea
  negotiations and potential sentences; and properly inform him of his right to
  appeal. 
The
  PCR judge held a hearing on Kolle's application.Â  At this hearing, plea counsel
  testified regarding the chronology of his representation of Kolle.Â  When he
  agreed to represent Kolle, plea counsel had been practicing law for
  approximately three years and had not yet represented a client with a felony
  charge.
At
  the onset of his representation, plea counsel received discovery materials from
  the solicitor's office that had been previously requested by Kolle's public
  defender.Â  Although plea counsel had limited discovery material, he believed
  the search that led to Kolle's charge was improper, particularly the lack of
  exigent circumstances.Â  In turn, plea counsel filed a motion to suppress the drug
  evidence. 
In
  recounting the suppression hearing, plea counsel conceded that he did not point
  out the discrepancies between the officers' testimony and the documentary
  evidence, which included the incident reports, the search warrant, and the
  police call logs.Â  Specifically, PCR counsel established that plea counsel
  failed to question the officers regarding the following time discrepancies:Â  the
  call/dispatch log indicated the loud music complaint was received at 12:43
  a.m.; Officer Canfora arrived at the apartment at 12:48 a.m.; the search warrant
  appears to indicate it was issued at 12:01 a.m. and executed at 12:43 a.m.Â  Plea
  counsel admitted that he did not have this documentary evidence in his file. Â He
  further acknowledged that he never requested the lab report or the chain of
  custody report regarding the cocaine that was seized pursuant to the search
  warrant.[2]Â  
In
  terms of plea negotiations, plea counsel testified that prior to the
  suppression hearing the State offered Kolle a sentence of ten years suspended
  upon the service of five years with three years' probation.[3]Â Â Â 
  Plea counsel admitted that he told Kolle the offer was not "a good deal,"
  but that it would remain open even after the suppression hearing.Â  He
  acknowledged that the offer did not remain open and was significantly less than
  the seven-year sentence Kolle received. 
At
  the beginning of his testimony, Kolle reiterated his allegations of ineffective
  assistance of counsel.Â  In explaining his dissatisfaction with plea counsel's
  representation, Kolle outlined his version of the facts and primarily argued
  that the search warrant and subsequent seizure of the cocaine was improper
  given there were no exigent circumstances for the initial entry. Â Kolle
  contended that the evidence could have been suppressed had plea counsel:Â 
  thoroughly investigated the case; filed a more inclusive discovery motion;
  interviewed the other co-defendants; pointed out during the suppression hearing
  the discrepancies between the call logs, the incident reports, and the search
  warrant; and identified errors in the chain of custody evidence form that was
  prepared for the cocaine. 
In
  terms of his decision to plead guilty, Kolle claimed he felt under duress to
  accept the plea because plea counsel was not prepared for trial. Additionally,
  Kolle asserted plea counsel provided incorrect information regarding the State's
  initial plea offer.Â  Specifically, Kolle contended plea counsel told him the
  offer was not a good deal and he should not accept it until after the suppression
  hearing.Â  Because he did not have accurate advice or information prior to the
  plea, Kolle claimed his decision to plead guilty was not knowing and
  voluntary.Â  
On
  cross-examination, Kolle acknowledged that he had admitted his guilt regarding
  the trafficking in cocaine charge at the plea proceeding as well as during his
  testimony at co-defendant Holmes's trial.Â  Kolle, however, explained that he
  pled guilty and expressed satisfaction with plea counsel's representation
  because he lacked the necessary information to raise any challenge during the
  plea proceeding.Â  
Following the
  hearing, the PCR judge granted Kolle's application and ordered a new trial.Â  In
  reaching this conclusion, the PCR judge found that plea counsel's failure to
  point out the discrepancies between the officers' testimony and the documentary
  evidence constituted ineffective assistance.Â  Specifically, the PCR judge
  believed that had plea counsel raised these issues at the suppression hearing,
  this information "would have resulted at the very minimum suppressing the
  evidence gained in the search warrant to sustain the evidence on the
  Trafficking charge."Â  
Additionally,
  the PCR judge found plea counsel was deficient in failing to properly advise
  Kolle regarding the State's plea offer.Â  Because plea counsel misadvised Kolle
  not to plead guilty prior to the suppression hearing, which in turn resulted in
  the withdrawal of the State's negotiated sentence, the PCR judge found that
  these facts "undermined the willful and voluntary nature of [Kolleâ€™s]
  plea."Â  
Finally,
  the PCR judge found plea counsel would have discovered exculpatory evidence regarding
  the search warrant and radio/dispatch logs had he properly prepared for trial.Â 
  The PCR judge believed "such discovery would have reversed the outcome."Â 
  Thus, the judge held that plea counsel's lack of preparation satisfied the
  standard of deficiency under Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668
  (1984).Â  Ultimately, the judge concluded that this deficient performance "deprived
  [Kolle] of adequate representation and that a different verdict from a verdict
  of guilty could have been a logical conclusion."Â  
The State filed a
  motion for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e) of the South Carolina Rules
  of Civil Procedure.Â  In a summary order, the PCR judge denied the State's
  motion.Â  
This Court granted
  the State's petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR judge's order. 
DISCUSSION
The State contends the PCR judge erred in finding that
  Kolle did not freely, knowingly, and voluntarily enter his guilty plea.Â  In
  support of this contention, the State asserts that plea counsel was not
  deficient in his representation of Kolle given he:Â  met with Kolle on multiple
  occasions prior to the entry of the plea; investigated the case; requested discovery;
  and thoroughly challenged the search which precipitated Kolle's arrest for the
  drug charge.Â  
Even if counsel's
  performance was deficient, the State claims Kolle failed to establish that he
  was prejudiced.Â  The State asserts that Kolle lacked standing to challenge the
  legality of the search and seizure, thus, negating Kolle's primary basis for
  contesting the drug charge.Â  Additionally, the State argues that Kolleâ€™s guilty
  plea "must stand due to the overwhelming evidence of his guilt."Â  
A
  defendant has the right to the effective assistance of counsel under the Sixth
  Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).Â  "There is a strong presumption that counsel
  rendered adequate assistance and exercised reasonable professional judgment in
  making all significant decisions in the case."Â  Ard v. Catoe, 372
  S.C. 318, 331, 642 S.E.2d 590, 596 (2007).Â Â  
In a
  PCR proceeding, the applicant bears the burden of establishing that he or she
  is entitled to relief.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 109, 525 S.E.2d
  514, 517 (2000).Â  "A defendant who enters a plea on the advice of counsel
  may only attack the voluntary and intelligent character of the plea by showing
  that counsel's representation fell below an objective standard of
  reasonableness and that there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel's
  errors, the defendant would not have pled guilty, but would have insisted on
  going to trial."Â  Rolen v. State, 384 S.C. 409, 413, 683 S.E.2d
  471, 474 (2009). Â "A
  reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in
  the outcome of trial." Â Johnson v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 186, 480
  S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â  "Plea counsel is ineffective within the meaning
  of the Sixth Amendment only when the applicant satisfies both requirements."Â  Stalk v. State, 383 S.C. 559, 561, 681 S.E.2d 592, 593 (2009).Â  Â 
"In determining guilty plea issues, it
  is proper to consider the guilty plea transcript as well as evidence at the PCR hearing." Â Suber v. State, 371 S.C. 554,
  558, 640 S.E.2d 884, 886 (2007).Â  "Specifically, the voluntariness of a
  guilty plea is not determined by an examination of a specific inquiry made by
  the sentencing judge alone, but is determined from both the record made at the
  time of the entry of the guilty plea, and also from the
  record of the PCR hearing." Â Roddy
    v. State, 339 S.C. 29, 33, 528 S.E.2d 418, 420 (2000).Â  "The
  longstanding test for determining the validity of a guilty plea is 'whether the
  plea represents a voluntary and intelligent choice among the alternative
  courses of action open to the defendant.'"Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 56 (1985) (quoting North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25, 31 (1970)).
In
  reviewing the PCR court's decision, an appellate court is concerned only with whether
  any evidence of probative value exists to support that decision.  Smith
    v. State, 369 S.C. 135, 138, 631 S.E.2d 260, 261 (2006).Â  We will uphold
  the findings of the PCR court when there is any evidence of probative value to
  support them, and will reverse the decision of the PCR court when it is
  controlled by an error of law.  Suber, 371 S.C. at 558-59, 640
  S.E.2d at 886.Â  "This Court gives great
  deference to the post-conviction relief (PCR) court's findings of fact and
  conclusions of law."Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 368, 610
  S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005).Â  
I.
As a
  threshold matter, we find the State's argument regarding Kolle's lack of
  standing was not preserved for this Court's consideration.Â  Based on our review
  of the record, the State did not raise this claim at the PCR hearing but did so
  only in its motion for reconsideration.Â  Therefore, this argument is not
  properly before the Court.Â  See Palacio v. State, 333 S.C. 506,
  514 n.7, 511 S.E.2d 62, 66 n.7 (1999) (concluding issue that was neither raised
  to nor ruled upon by the PCR court was not preserved for appellate review); see
    also Johnson v. Sonoco Prods. Co., 381 S.C. 172, 177, 672 S.E.2d 567,
  570 (2009) (recognizing that an issue may not be raised for the first time in a
  motion to reconsider).Â  
Even
  if properly preserved, we disagree with the State's assertion that Kolle lacked
  standing to challenge the search and seizure which precipitated his arrest for
  the drug charge.Â  The fact that Kolle did not own or lease the apartment that
  was searched does not negate his standing to challenge the search and
  subsequent seizure.Â  Following the decisions of the United States Supreme
  Court, this Court has definitively held that an overnight guest has a
  reasonable expectation of privacy, the legal prerequisite to confer standing on
  an individual.Â  See State v. Missouri, 361 S.C. 107, 603 S.E.2d
  594 (2004) (citing Minnesota v. Olson, 495 U.S. 91 (1990) and concluding
  that defendant, who on several occasions in the past and the occasion in
  question stayed at the searched apartment, had a reasonable expectation of
  privacy to challenge the search and seizure which resulted in his charge of
  trafficking in crack cocaine).Â  Here, there was evidence that Holmes, the
  person who leased the apartment, befriended Kolle and permitted him to stay for
  an extended period of time at the residence.Â Â Â  Accordingly, Kolle had a
  reasonable expectation of privacy in the apartment and, thus, had standing to
  challenge the search.
II.
Finding
  that Kolle had standing, we address the remainder of the State's arguments.Â  
A
  determination of the core issue of ineffective assistance of counsel requires a
  two-part assessment.Â  We find it is necessary to determine whether plea counsel
  was ineffective:Â  (1) with respect to Kolle's fundamental decision to plead
  guilty; and (2) regarding Kolle's decision to reject the State's initial plea
  offer and enter a plea without a negotiated sentence.
A.
Cognizant of this
  Court's recent pronouncements regarding guilty plea challenges and its standard
  of review, there is evidence to support the PCR judge's determination that plea
  counsel was ineffective in advising Kolle to plead guilty.Â  
Initially,
  we agree with the PCR judge's decision that plea counsel was deficient in
  failing to procure pertinent discovery materials, in particular the
  call/dispatch logs and the search warrant.Â  If plea counsel had these
  materials, he could have effectively cross-examined the officers at the
  suppression hearing and pointed out the time discrepancies and the following
  additional discrepancies:Â  (1) the arrest warrant affidavit, the incident
  reports, and the search warrant refer to the drug evidence as crack cocaine as
  opposed to powder cocaine; and (2) the investigative report and the affidavit
  in support of the search warrant do not reference the "fresh damage" or
  "forced entry" to the apartment door as testified to by Officer
  Canfora to justify the exigent circumstances for entry into the apartment. Â Had
  plea counsel adequately attacked the credibility of the officers, there is a
  reasonable probability this would have influenced the trial judge's decision
  regarding the existence of exigent circumstances, i.e., affected the
  outcome of the suppression motion.Â Â  
Moreover,
  if plea counsel truly believed the suppression issue was meritorious, he could
  have advised Kolle to proceed to trial and, if convicted, challenge the denial
  of the suppression motion on direct appeal.
B.
Given there is
  evidence to support the PCR judge's finding that plea counsel was ineffective
  with respect to his representation regarding the suppression hearing and, in
  turn, Kolle's decision to plead guilty, we need not address the remaining
  issue.Â  
However,
  in the interest of thoroughness, we review the remaining issue of whether plea
  counsel was ineffective in advising Kolle to reject the State's initial plea
  offer and plead guilty without a negotiated sentence.
We find plea
  counsel was deficient in advising Kolle that the State's initial plea offer was
  not a "good deal" and misinforming Kolle that the offer would remain
  open until after the suppression hearing.Â  
Clearly,
  the State's offer of a sentence of ten years suspended on the service of five
  years with three years' probation was significantly better than the seven to
  twenty-five-year sentence Kolle faced for the trafficking charge.[4]Â 
  Moreover, plea counsel advised him not to plead guilty until after the
  suppression hearing at which time the State withdrew the plea offer. Â Had Kolle
  known that the State would withdraw this offer after the suppression hearing,
  he may have decided to accept it and received a lower sentence.Â  Cf.Â  Davie
    v. State, 381 S.C. 601, 675 S.E.2d 416 (2009) (concluding petitioner proved
  ineffective assistance of counsel where plea counsel failed to communicate the
  State's proposed plea offer which was a significantly lower sentence than
  petitioner would have accepted had it been communicated).[5]
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find there is evidence to
  support the decision of the PCR judge.Â  Accordingly, the order granting Kolle's
  PCR application is
AFFIRMED.
WALLER, J.,
  concurs. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion. KITTREDGE, J.,
  dissenting in a separate opinion in which TOAL, C.J., concurs.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that we must affirm the
  post-conviction relief (PCR) judge's order granting respondent PCR.Â  Our scope
  of review is limited to whether there is any evidence of probative value in the
  record to support the PCR judge's findings,Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C.
  115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989), and we give great deference to the PCR judge's
  credibility determinations.Â  Drayton v. Evatt, 312 S.C. 4, 430 S.E.2d
  517 (1993).Â  This deference requires that we accept the PCR judge's finding
  that a witness is credible even where the PCR testimony is directly refuted by
  the trial or guilty plea record.Â  See Solomon v. State, 313 S.C.
  526, 443 S.E.2d 540 (1994).Â  Given our limited scope of review, and the
  deference accorded the PCR judge's credibility determinations, I concur in the
  result reached by the majority here.

JUSTICE
  KITTREDGE:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â 
  I vote to reverse and reinstate the guilty plea and sentence.
The
  plea judge, the Honorable Steven H. John, conducted a thorough and textbook
  guilty plea.Â  J. Lamar Kolle pled guilty freely and voluntarily, and
  acknowledged satisfaction with plea counsel.Â  

  THE
    COURT:Â Â  Now, you are here with your attorney . . . is that correct?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  Yes, sir.
  THE
    COURT:Â  Have you told him everything you need to tell him about this case?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  I believe so, sir.
  THE
    COURT:Â  All right, sir.Â  Have you had enough time to talk to him?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  Yes, sir.
  THE
    COURT:Â  Do you need any more time to talk to him?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  No, sir.
  THE
    COURT:Â  Has he done everything that you expected of him, that you wanted him to
    do to try to help you in this case?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  Yes, sir.
  THE
    COURT:Â  Are you satisfied with his representation?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  Yes, sir.
  THE
    COURT:Â  Any complaints about his representations?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  No, sir.

The
  guilty plea colloquy, including allocution, revealed the following facts.Â  In
  the summer of 2003, Kolle and â€œladiesâ€ traveled from Ohio to North Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.Â  Kolle and his lady friends were befriended by Willis Holmes, who invited the group â€œto stay at his house and save on the hotel bill.â€Â  
The
  cocaine was found in Holmesâ€™s residence.Â  According to the plea allocution: 

  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  I let Mr. Willis Holmes know what me and the ladies had in our possession,
    and he said that wouldnâ€™t be an issue, but he would prefer that it stayed
    outside of the house.
  It
    stayed outside of the house, in my vehicle, for the first three or four days,
    and then once Mr. Holmes started selling it and purchasing it, it came in the
    house, and he knew that because he had asked for some in the house, and
    received it in the house from me, and it stayed in the house from that time
    on.Â  I demonstrated the machine to Mr. Holmes also, so he was well aware of
    what was going on.
  THE COURT:Â 
    All right, sir.Â  
  Solicitor,
    anything further that you would like to ask Mr. Kolle at this time?
  SOLICITOR:Â 
    Your Honor, I would ask that - in his allocution he indicated the â€œstuff.â€Â 
    What would that â€œstuffâ€ be?
  THE
    COURT:Â  Mr. Kolle.
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  The cocaine ---
  THE
    COURT:Â  All right.
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  ---And the tools.Â  
  THE COURT:Â  And
    the paraphernalia that was seized by the police; is that correct?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  Yes sir.
  THE
    COURT:Â  All right, sir.Â  And the weight that - of the cocaine that was seized,
    in your estimation, that was a correct amount as far as the weight at the time
    that it was seized, as best you could tell?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  I believe it is a little heavy, and if you review the documents there
    are several different amounts that the police have come up with, and thatâ€™s
    going to be due to moisture and sweating, so I would ---
  THE
    COURT:Â  All right.Â  But itâ€™s no question in your mind it was certainly a good
    deal bit more than twenty-eight grams?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  Yes.
  THE COURT:Â 
    All right.Â  Now, Mr. Kolle, just a second.Â  I just have one or two other
    questions for you.Â  Regarding the answers that you have given me here today,
    are they the truth?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  Yes.
  THE
    COURT:Â  And did anybody tell you, or give you the answers that you have given
    to the Court, or are they your answers?
  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  They are my answers.

Following the trial
  of Holmes, Kolle appeared for sentencing before Judge John.Â  Kolle recited the
  reasons he believed he was a good candidate for probation:

  DEFENDANT
    KOLLE:Â  I just wanted to let the Court know that I was offered some pleas that
    were a lesser sentence than this, and it was not the fact that I was not trying
    to accept responsibility for the crime, but as informed by my attorney, he felt
    that it was an illegal search and seizure, so thatâ€™s why I took it to this
    point, and I feel like I kind of lost out a little bit because of that, and I
    just want to say that I do accept responsibility for what happened, but in the
    same light, these girls, they were of equal responsibility.Â  They have known
    whatâ€™s gone on, and I think that is apparent by their own statement.Â  They
    received a hundred day plea and some probation.Â  Iâ€™m not - I feel that I should
    pay for my crime, but however, I have seven kids which, you know what Iâ€™m
    saying, are in dire need of my support, and I just request that the Court have
    mercy on me and grant me probation.Â  I successfully have completed parole in Ohio when I - on my prior offense, with no problems, and I would not be a threat to
    society, and I feel that Iâ€™m a good candidate for probation.
  THE
    COURT:Â  Iâ€™m going to look at one thing first, before I impose a sentence in
    this matter.Â  . . .Â  [N]o probation is possible regarding this particular
    matter.Â  The court does feel that the minimum sentence should be imposed in
    this offense that is allowable by law, and that would be the sentence of seven
    years.Â  That is the sentence in this particular matter.

According
  to Kolleâ€™s PCR testimony, when he pled guilty he was aware of plea counselâ€™s
  alleged deficient representation and repeatedly complained to counsel about
  it.Â  For example, Kolle testified that he and counsel â€œactually debated about
  this beforehandâ€; Kolle â€œcontinued to argue with [counsel] and he continued to
  try not to do itâ€ when counsel apparently failed to investigate the case as
  instructed by Kolle; and Kolle testified that â€œ[counsel] didnâ€™t investigate my
  case whatsoever or follow my instructions concerning the investigation of my
  case.â€[6]
Kolleâ€™s
  PCR testimony stands in stark contrast to his guilty plea testimony.Â 
  Presumably, Kolle lied to the plea judge in stating he was satisfied with
  counsel and had no complaints.Â  It is my
  view that a guilty plea is not rendered involuntary where, as here, a defendant
  knowingly testifies falsely at the guilty plea proceeding.[7]Â  I would not
  grant a PCR applicant relief under such circumstances.Â  I find no evidence to
  support the PCR court's decision and would reverse the grant of PCR.Â  
TOAL, C.J.,
  concurs.


[1]Â Hakes and Everhart gave statements in which they
  identified Kolle as the primary participant in the drug activity.Â  
[2]Â Through another witness, PCR counsel attempted to
  establish that there was a ten-day "break" in the chain of custody
  for the cocaine.Â  
[3]Â Kolle's PCR counsel played a tape of a conversation
  between Kolle and plea counsel that substantiated this plea offer.Â  
[4]Â Â In making this offer, the State would have reduced
  Kolle's indicted charge to trafficking in cocaine in an amount greater than ten
  grams but less than twenty-eight grams, which would not constitute a violent
  offense.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(e)(2)(a)(1) (2002) (providing for sentence
  of a term of imprisonment of not less than three years nor more than ten years
  for a first offense).
[5] The dissent appears to contend that a defendant may
  never raise a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel following the entry of
  a guilty plea if he expressed satisfaction with his attorney during the plea
  colloquy.Â  An expression of satisfaction with plea counsel is necessarily
  conditional.Â  The extent of satisfaction is dependent upon the attorney's
  diligence and degree of information shared with the client.Â  Although a plea of
  guilty may preclude certain PCR claims, it would not preclude those that directly
  involve the voluntariness and knowledge with which the guilty plea was made.Â 
  Here, Kolle entered his guilty plea without the benefit of all exculpatory
  information or knowledge that the State's initial plea offer would not remain
  open.Â  Because Kolle was unaware of this information, his claim of ineffective
  assistance of counsel clearly impinged upon the voluntariness and knowledge
  with which he entered his plea.Â  Accordingly, we find this case constitutes a
  valid collateral attack of a guilty plea.Â  See Davila v. United
    States, 258 F.3d 448, 451 (6th Cir. 2001) (considering question of whether
  a plea agreement that waives the right to file for post-conviction relief is
  enforceable when the petition claims ineffective assistance of counsel and
  holding that "[w]hen a defendant knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily
  waives the right to collaterally attack his or her sentence, he or she is
  precluded from bring[ing] a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel"); Watts
    v. State, 248 S.W.3d 725, 729 (Mo. Ct. App. 2008) ("Where . . . Â there
  is a negotiated plea of guilty, a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel is
  immaterial except to the extent that it impinges upon the voluntariness and
  knowledge with which the guilty plea was made." (citation omitted)); cf. Spoone v. State, 379 S.C. 138, 665 S.E.2d 605 (2008) (concluding
  appellate rights and post-conviction review may be waived by a knowingly and
  voluntarily entered guilty plea pursuant to a written plea agreement).
[6] Moreover, Kolle fancies himself as a legal expert, as
  reflected in his lecture-like testimony to the PCR court on the laws of search
  and seizure and Brady.Â  
[7] The majority opinion states that I â€œappear[]
  to contend that a defendant may never raise a claim of ineffective assistance of
  counsel following the entry of a guilty plea if he expressed satisfaction with
  his attorney during the plea colloquy.â€Â  I contend no such thing.Â  I contend
  that a defendant should not be permitted to successfully collaterally challenge
  a guilty plea on the basis of an involuntary plea tied to a claim of deficient
  representation where: (1) the alleged deficient representation was known to the
  defendant at the time of the guilty plea; and (2) the defendant knowingly
  testified falsely at the plea proceeding concerning plea counselâ€™s
  representation.
